evidence: Assisted by a nurse at the scene Transported home by parents

key_points: Patient 11 years old with history of bicycle accident involving head and leg impact, with brief loss of consciousness.
Presented with headache and leg pain; no significant back pain.
Physical exam shows minor bruise on right knee and abrasion on hand and arm; vitals normal, normal speech and mobility.
Management: Reassurance, education on short-term and long-term effects of concussion; advice to return to ED if concerns arise in next 24-48 hours.

evidence: Vitals normal, Minor bruise, Normal speech and mobility
attendance_complexity.rationale: The patient has a single complaint (headache and leg pain), no vital-sign red flags, no advanced investigations, no procedural interventions, and no signs of instability. Management is limited to reassurance and education. This fits 'ordinary complexity' as defined by single issue and basic work-up.

candidate.description_original: Management, without aftercare, of all fractures and dislocations suffered by a patient that: (a) is provided by a medical practitioner (except a specialist in the practice of the specialist's specialty of emergency medicine) in conjunction with an attendance on the patient by the practitioner described in item 5021, 5022, 5027, 5030, 5031, 5032, 5033, 5035 or 5036; and (b) occurs at a recognised emergency department of a private hospital (Anaes.)
